sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a dissolution reaction
message_1: What is the standard enthalpy change (in kJ/mol) when 10.0 g of potassium chloride (KCl) dissolves in water at 25°C? The molar mass of KCl is 74.55 g/mol and the enthalpy of solution is -17.76 kJ/mol.
message_2:
To find the standard enthalpy change when 10.0 g of potassium chloride (KCl) dissolves in water, we first need to determine the number of moles of KCl in 10.0 g.

moles of KCl = mass / molar mass
moles of KCl = 10.0 g / 74.55 g/mol = 0.134 moles

Now, we can use the enthalpy of solution to find the standard enthalpy change for this amount of KCl.

Standard enthalpy change = moles × enthalpy of solution
Standard enthalpy change = 0.134 moles × (-17.76 kJ/mol) = -2.38 kJ

So, the standard enthalpy change when 10.0 g of potassium chloride dissolves in water at 25°C is -2.38 kJ.
